children.name: good at sth because you have experience or training
skilful
children.definition: British /skillfulAmerican /ˈskɪlfəl/  someone who is skilful does something very well because they have had a lot of training or experience:
examples: khéo tay , chuyên nghiệp
▪ the artist’s skillful use of color
kỹ năng phối màu chuyên nghiệp
▪ Success in business depends on skilful management.
Thành công trong doanh nghiệp dựa trên sự khéo quản lý.
▪ Skilful and confident, Donaldson should become one of the game’s best players.
Khéo léo và tự tin, Donaldson trở thành cầu thủ giỏi nhất giải đấu.
skilfulUK,USskillfuladjective khéo léo;thành thạo
good atdoing something, especially because you have practised doing it
_Police officers have to be skilful drivers.

children.name: skilled
children.definition: /skɪld/  someone who isskilledata particular job has the training and skill to do it well:
examples: lành nghề, nhiều kinh nghiệm, khéo tay
▪ There is a demand for carpenters and other skilled craftsmen.
Có nhu cầu về thợ mộc và các thợ thủ công lành nghề khác.
skilled job/ workrequiring special skill, especially when you use your hands
công việc đòi hỏi kỹ năng
▪ Shoeing a horse is a skilled job, and no unskilled person should try it.
Đóng móng sắt cho ngựa là công việc đòi hỏi sự khéo léo, và không một người không lành nghề nào nên thử.
highly skilledvery skilled
tay nghề cao
▪ Keeping highly skilled sailors in the Navy is a priority.
Giữ chân những thợ may tay nghề cao ở lại Navy là ưu tiên hàng đầu.
skilled at doing something
khéo léo trong việc gì
▪ Our advisors are skilled at dealing with financial problems.
Các cố vấn của chúng tôi rất giỏi trong việc giải quyết các vấn đề tài chính.
skilledadjective khéo léo;thành thạo
having the abilities needed to do an activity or job well
_My mother is very skilledat/indressmaking.

children.name: expert
children.definition: /ˈekspɜːʳt/  extremely skilful at doing something because you have gained a lot of knowledge or experience of this particular subject or activity over a long period of time:
examples: thành thạo, lão luyện
▪ Students learn to cook French food with the help of expert chefs.
Học viên học nấu món Pháp với sự giúp đỡ của đầu bếp lão luyện.
▪ My grandmother was an expert dressmaker.
Bà tôi là một thợ may lão luyện.
expert at/ in
thành thạo/ tinh thông về
▪ Politicians are usually expert at turning a crisis to their advantage.
Các chính trị gia thường rất giỏi trong việc biến khó khăn thành lợi thế của mình.
expert help/ advice/ opinion etcgiven by someone who knows a lot about it
sự giúp đỡ/ lời khuyên/ ý kiến chuyên gia
▪ Tennis coaches will be available to provide expert advice.
Huấn luyện viên quần vợt luôn có mặt để cung cấp những lời khuyên chuyên gia.
expertly[adverb]
chuyên nghiệp
▪ The campaign was well-publicised and expertly co-ordinated.
Chiến dịch được công bố rộng rãi và tổ chức một cách chuyên nghiệp.
expertadjective[before noun ]tinh thông; lão luyện; cótài
having or showing a lot of knowledge or skill
_The centre provides expertadvicefor people with financial problems.
_What's your expertopinion?
_an expert fisherman

children.name: know what you’re doing U
children.definition: know what you’re doing/ˌnəʊ wɒt jɔːʳ ˈduːɪŋ/  spoken use this to say that someone is good at doing something and you admire and trust them because of this:
examples: biết mình đang làm gì
▪ Kids can tell if a teacher doesn’t know what he’s doing.
Trẻ con biết ngay khi một giáo viên không biết mình đang làm gì.
▪ You seem to know what you’re doing -- I’ll leave you to it.
Bạn có vẻ biết việc mình đang làm- tôi sẽ để việc này cho bạn.

children.name: adept
children.definition: /ˈædept, əˈdeptǁəˈdept/  good at doing something that needs care and skill, for example dealing with people or with difficult social situations:
examples: giỏi, khéo
adept at/ in
giỏi, khéo trong
▪ Of all our staff, Peter is the most adept at dealing with difficult customers.
Trong số những nhân viên, Peter là người giỏi nhất trong việc giải quyết khách hàng khó tính.
▪ McCrea was equally adept in comedy and drama.
McCrea đều giỏi cả hài lẫn kịch.

children.name: accomplished
children.definition: /əˈkʌmplɪʃtǁəˈkɑːm-, əˈkʌm-/  someone who is very good at writing, acting, or other artistic skills, especially as a result of a lot of practice and training, but who does not usually have a special natural ability for it:
examples: tài năng
▪ His two daughters are both accomplished athletes.
Hai cô con gái của ông ta đều là những vận động viên tài năng.
highly accomplished
tài giỏi
▪ Johann Sebastian Bach had three sons who all became highly accomplished musicians and composers.
Johann Sebastian Bach có ba người con trai đều trở thành những nhạc công và nhà soạn nhạc tài ba.

children.name: have a good command of
children.definition: /hæv ə ˌgʊd kəˈmɑːnd ɒvǁ-ˈmænd-/  to know a subject, especially a language, well and be good at it:
examples: thông thạo
▪ Candidates should have good typing skills and a good command of English.
Các ứng viên nên có kỹ năng đánh máy tốt và thông thạo tiếng Anh.
▪ She has an excellent command of all the facts.
Cô ấy tinh thông mọi vấn đề.

children.name: can do sth in your sleep
children.definition: can do something in your sleep/kən ˌduː something ɪn jɔːʳ ˈsliːp/ informalto be able to do something very easily because you have done it a lot of times before:
examples: nhắm mắt mà chơi
▪ I’ve played this piece so often I can practically do it in my sleep.
Tôi đã chơi bản này nhiều đến mức tôi có thể nhắm mắt mà chơi.

children.name: the ability to do sth well gained by learning and practising
knack
children.definition: a special skill for doing a particular thing, especially a simple everyday thing :tài
examples: knack for doing sth
Some people seem to have a knack for making money.
He has a knack for making people feel relaxed.
knack of doing sth
Thomson’s knack of scoring vital goals makes him important to the team.
have a knackHe seems to have a knack for getting people to agree with him.
get the knack
Once you've got the knack, you'll never forget how to do it.
Breadmaking is easy once you get the knack.
lose the knackHe proved that he hadn't lost the knack for scoring goals.
an uncanny knack(= an ability that seems surprising or strange )She has an uncanny knack for knowing what you're really thinking.
an unhappy knack(= a knack that you would not want )He had the unhappy knack of making enemies.

children.name: skill
children.definition: an ability to do sth well, especially because you have learned and practised it: kỹ năng
examples: Reading and writing are two different skills.
Many jobs today require computer skills.
skill in/at
He was valued for his skill in raising money for the company.
with skill
The whole team played with great skill and determination.
have a skillHe didn’t have the right skills for the job.
learn a skill(alsoacquire a skillformal)People can acquire new skills while they are unemployed.
develop a skillWe will give you the opportunity to develop your skills.
use a skillI am sure you can use your communication skills to get your message across.
require/take skill(= to need skill )It’s a difficult task, which requires skill and experience.
lack a skill(= not have a skill )He lacked both the skills and the confidence to take on the job.
hone a skill(= improve it )The course will help you hone your writing skills.
master a skill(= learn it so that your skill is very good )Many of these children have not mastered basic academic skills.
great/considerable skill(= a lot of skill )He played with great skill.
good skillsHe’s got good management skills.
basic skillsThe basic skills can be acquired very quickly.
practical skillsStudents will have the opportunity to learn a lot of practical skills.
technical skillsGood technical skills are not enough.
management skillsShe needs to develop her management skills.
computer/IT skillsWe’re looking for someone with good IT skills.
reading/writing skillsTheir reading skills are poor.
communication skills(= the ability to communicate well with people )The nurse must use her communication skills to help the patient feel at ease.
social skills(= the ability to get on well with people )Unsociable toddlers were found to have poor social skills later.
people/interpersonal skills(= the ability to deal with people )He wasn’t a good communicator and had no people skills at all.
language skills(= the ability to use a language )We need to hire people with useful language skills.
